page.title: 07Queen Elizabeth Forest
page.content: The proportion of woodland to farmland is unusually high in this section of the South Downs, probably 50/50. These woodlands are in large blocks and their ownership is fairly equally divided between the State in the form of Forestry Commission (which owns the Queen Elizabeth Forest) and private estates or farms. Speceis generally grown are beech, ash, pine, fir, spruce and a wide variety of minor speceis. Most of the produce, resulting from these woodlands is transported by lorry to pulp mills in Gloucestershire or Kent. There is only one sawmill at Buriton and this is a specialist mill using larch timber imported for the production of larch- lap fences. It is sited in an old chalk pit. Approximately 15 people depend on forestry for a living within the study.
